headline: Gang Fight Kills 57 in Brazil, 16 Beheaded
summary: A gang fight in a prison in Brazil’s Para state left at least 57 dead, many by decapitation or asphyxiation, adding to a string of gruesome clashes in the country’s overloaded prison system as the government struggles to fight rampant crime.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of July 30, 2019

headline: Wealthy Parents Transfer Guardianship of Teens to Get Aid
summary: The Education Department is looking into a tactic that has been used in some Chicago suburbs, in which wealthy parents transfer legal guardianship of their college-bound children to relatives or friends so the teens can claim financial aid.

headline: Shooter at Gilroy Garlic Festival in California Used Semiautomatic Rifle
summary: The suspected shooter used an AK-47-style semiautomatic rifle to kill a 6-year-old boy, a 13-year-old girl and a man in his 20s in Sunday’s attack at the Gilroy Garlic Festival, police said.

headline: Led by Trump and Johnson, Disrupters Rise Globally
summary: The most important trend in global politics is the rise of disrupters like President Trump, who gained power by taking a wrecking ball to the prevailing political system. Last week’s ascension of British Prime Minister Boris Johnson was the latest instance of this phenomenon.

headline: Justice Department Fills Fraud Section Post Long in Limbo
summary: Robert Zink was one of two prosecutors to occupy the position on an interim basis after the section’s former chief, Andrew Weissmann, joined special counsel Robert Mueller’s team in 2017 to investigate Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.

headline: Cloud Computing Is Here. Cloud Recycling Is Next.
summary: The world’s $300 billion scrap-metal market is looking beyond junked cars and copy machines to a new prize: the cloud. Pilot efforts are under way to handle the recycling of small amounts of cloud-computing material in the U.S., betting on a sharp pickup in volumes in the years ahead.

headline: Federal Borrowing Soars as Deficit Fear Fades
summary: Borrowing by the federal government is set to top $1 trillion for the second year in a row as higher spending outpaces revenue growth and concern about budget deficits wanes in Washington and on Wall Street.

headline: The Confusing Federal Reserve
summary: The second-quarter GDP report did not make the case for easing.

headline: Smearing Mitch McConnell
summary: Democrats and the media distort his record on Russia.

headline: Big Pharma vs. Big Pharma
summary: Pfizer’s deal with Mylan may make both more competitive.

headline: New York City Is Hunting for School Space
summary: New York City officials, having a hard time finding sites for new public schools, say they will soon advertise to recruit potential property sellers.

headline: A Fed Reversal Will Store Up Trouble
summary: The central bank may cut interest rates when asset prices are high and unemployment low. Why?

headline: California Wants to Teach Your Kids That Capitalism Is Racist
summary: A new model curriculum for ‘ethnic studies’ is a handbook for classroom propagandizing.

headline: Environmental Extremists Favor Mosquitoes Over Mankind
summary: Genetically altered insects could save millions from malaria but are anathema to ‘agroecologists.’

headline: ‘The College Dropout Scandal’ Review: A Matter of Degree
summary: Some schools have made student success their top priority and are ﬁnding effective, hands-on ways to increase graduation rates.

headline: The Battle of the Microwave
summary: At 13, my brother beat my father in an epic domestic conflict.

headline: Mayor Pete Has a Race Problem
summary: Buttigieg has even less black support than the president he calls a racist.

headline: Rig Owners Forecast Further Drilling Decline
summary: Drilling rig owners and others who lease equipment to U.S. energy producers are forecasting a slowdown in activity during the second half of the year.

headline: Notable & Quotable: Blame Taxes for Baltimore’s Rot
summary: ‘Those of us who live in Baltimore are often asked whether our city really is the hellhole it is portrayed to be on TV.’

headline: Why Russia and China Are Joining Forces
summary: The past few years have witnessed a marked increase in American power.

headline: Beyond Meat On Track to Deliver Profit This Year
summary: Beyond Meat said sales of its plant-based burgers and sausages continued to surge, though shares dropped after hours on plans to issue more stock.

headline: Senate Fails to Block Arms Sales to Saudi Arabia, U.A.E.
summary: A congressional effort to block certain arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates fell short after the Senate failed to override President Trump’s veto of the measures.

headline: U.S. Soccer Says Women’s Team Has Been Paid More Than Men’s Team
summary: The U.S. Soccer Federation released a letter from its president saying that it has paid the women’s team more than the men’s national team in recent years.

headline: Remixes Propel Lil Nas X’s ‘Old Town Road’ to Billboard Chart Record
summary: The country-rap hit became the longest-running No. 1 song in Billboard chart history, beating out the 16-week record held in a tie between Mariah Carey and Boyz II Men since 1996 and Luis Fonsi and Daddy Yankee since 2017.

headline: Refinancing Boom Boosts Mortgage Lending
summary: Lenders made $565 billion of mortgage loans in the second quarter, the most in more than two years. Falling rates encouraged homeowners to refinance.

headline: Bank of America, First Data End Payments Partnership
summary: Bank of America is disbanding its payment-processing joint venture with First Data, giving the bank more control of its business that focuses on moving money for merchants.

headline: Strong Earnings Allay Fears Over Trade and Growth—for Now
summary: Corporate profits are proving to be more resilient than expected in the second quarter, nudging the stock market higher this month and distracting from anxieties about trade and economic growth.

headline: London Stock Exchange’s Big Bet Is Profitable but Risky
summary: For now, investors are more focused on the profit potential of the LSE’s $15 billion acquisition of Refinitiv than on the financial and operational hurdles.

headline: Mylan CFO Set to Leave as Part of Pfizer Deal
summary: Mylan Chief Financial Officer Ken Parks, who has been in the role since June 2016, will retire from the company upon the close of the transaction that will see Pfizer combine its off-patent drugs business with Mylan. Mylan Chief Executive Heather Bresch will also depart, the companies said.

headline: SoftBank’s New Fund Stands to Shake Up Enterprise Tech
summary: SoftBank’s $108 billion technology fund will have a big impact on the venture-backed startups helping to develop next-generation enterprise technology, investors say.

headline: A Public Option Is No Winner for Democrats
summary: While it’s true that most Americans don’t want “a radical change tearing up existing plans,” a “public option” health care system would ultimately do just that.

headline: Smaller Money Managers Drowning in Rules
summary: Further regulating small advisers, who are already swamped by regulatory requirements, will serve only to put more good people out of business.

headline: British Pound Collapse Continues
summary: The British pound on Tuesday came under continued assault, sliding as traders price in an increased possibility of a so-called hard Brexit.

headline: Dealing With the High Price of Some Insulin
summary: I have serious diabetes mellitus and have managed it with Lilly insulin for a decade for under $100 a month. Tens of thousands do likewise.

headline: Blame Obama, not Kerry For the Terrible Iran Deal
summary: You imply that the “decider,” as President George W. Bush described himself, is Mr. Kerry, not President Obama.

headline: Melinda Katz Is Certified Winner of Queens District Attorney Primary
summary: Melinda Katz was officially certified the winner of the Democratic primary for Queens district attorney, the New York City Board of Elections said, setting up a legal battle between the longtime politician and the insurgent campaign of Tiffany Cabán.

headline: Higher Costs Hold Down Profit at Heineken
summary: Higher costs held down profit in the first half of the year for Heineken, despite the world’s second biggest brewer selling more beer globally and launching its nonalcoholic Heineken variant in the U.S.

headline: ‘The Big Day’ by Chance the Rapper Review: A Hip-Hop Missive From Married Life
summary: The Chicago rapper ruminates on his recent union with a new record that runs well over an hour, digging into weighty themes with an array of big-name guests.

headline: Ryanair Warns of Possible Job and Flight Cuts
summary: The Irish discount airline said further delays in the return to service of Boeing’s 737 MAX would lead to job cuts and less flying during next year’s peak summer travel season.

headline: Trump, Cummings, Pelosi and Baltimore
summary: Democrats have run the violent city longer than most of its residents have been alive.

headline: U.S. Sanctions North Korean Over Illicit Trade, Missile Program
summary: The U.S. imposed sanctions on a North Korean man it accuses of evading trade restrictions and being an employee of a government department that helped develop the nuclear-capable missiles the country fired last week.

headline: Welsh Carson Closes Its Biggest Fund at $4.3 Billion
summary: Private-equity investor Welsh Carson Anderson & Stowe has closed the largest fund in its four-decade history, collecting $4.3 billion for its 13th investment vehicle, according to people familiar with the situation.

headline: Netflix Splurges on Big-Budget Movies
summary: Netflix is spending hundreds of millions of dollars to produce big-budget films as it attempts to shore up its subscriber base and push further into territory once controlled by major Hollywood studios.

headline: Pfizer Is Buying Low and Smart in Generics Gambit
summary: Generics deal with Mylan fits well with strategy of new Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla.

headline: S&P 500 Ticks Lower as Expected Fed Rate Cut Looms
summary: The S&P 500 inched lower as investors looked ahead to a key Federal Reserve meeting that many anticipate will result in the first interest-rate cut since 2008.

headline: Venezuela’s Citgo Stake Can Be Seized, Appeals Court Says
summary: A U.S. appeals court said Venezuela’s stake in U.S.-based oil refiner Citgo Petroleum Corp. could be seized to satisfy a judgment against the country, a blow to its U.S.-backed opposition government.

headline: Delivery Startups Join Forces, Beefing Up for Battle With Uber, Amazon
summary: Two of the largest food-delivery companies in Europe are poised to join forces in a merger worth $11.1 billion, as they seek an edge in the competition against market dominators like Uber Technologies and Amazon.com.

headline: U.S. Stocks Could Be Headed for a Fall
summary: Four recent stock swoons have something in common: Almost exactly two months after the declines, stocks plummeted again. A drop in the S&P 500 started at the end of April and hit bottom in early June. Two months from that trough is early August.

headline: Uber Cuts Third of Marketing Staff; Lyft COO Exits
summary: Ride-hailing rivals Uber and Lyft went through separate staff shake-ups, as Uber cut about 400 jobs in its marketing department and Lyft eliminated its chief operating officer role.

headline: Mike Pompeo to Meet With Allies and Rivals on Asia-Pacific Tour
summary: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will tackle a number of the U.S.’s most critical foreign policy issues across the Asia-Pacific region when he jets off to a series of meetings this week in Thailand, Australia and elsewhere.

headline: Russian Activist Navalny Returns to Jail After Mystery Illness
summary: Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was discharged from a hospital, where he was being treated for a mysterious illness, and returned to jail to finish serving time for organizing unauthorized protests, amid claims from his supporters that he may have been poisoned.

headline: Reinvigorating the Classical Tradition
summary: The Mostly Mozart Festival brought fresh zest to the classical music world in an evening of three short concerts, including a performance by Finnish violinist Pekka Kuusisto of Vivaldi’s ‘Four Seasons’ with improvisation.

headline: Trump Commutes Prison Sentences in Medicaid Bribery, Drug Cases
summary: President Trump commuted the prison sentence of an Arkansas man convicted of bribery and a Florida man convicted of distributing synthetic marijuana, and pardoned five other individuals.

headline: Swiss Central Bank Fires Warning Shot on Currency
summary: The Swiss central bank appears to have taken its most significant steps to weaken the Swiss franc in two years as looming rate cuts abroad strengthened the currency.

headline: Attorney General Blocks Asylum Applications Based on Family Ties
summary: Attorney General William Barr is moving to cut off asylum for people whose claims are based on being related to persecuted family members, in the Trump administration’s latest effort to restrict who is eligible to seek refugee status in the U.S.

headline: Kamala Harris Unveils Plan to Transform Health Care to a Federal System
summary: Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Kamala Harris released a plan Monday to reshape the U.S. health-care system by transforming it over 10 years to a federal one that would still allow a limited role for private insurers.

headline: Shooting at Gilroy Garlic Festival in California Kills Three, Injures Several
summary: Three people were killed and 15 were injured in a shooting at the Gilroy Garlic Festival in California. One suspect was killed by police and officers were searching for another possible suspect.

headline: Facebook Watch Draws More Advertisers—Gradually
summary: Advertisers are beginning to direct more money toward Facebook Watch, but the video-viewing platform remains far behind YouTube in revenue and audience.

headline: Oil Giant to Host a Deserted Meeting
summary: Saudi Aramco will host its first investor call in mid-August.

headline: Gov. Cuomo Signs Bill Decriminalizing Marijuana Use
summary: The penalties for possessing and smoking marijuana in New York will be loosened in 30 days under a new law that supporters say will lead to fewer arrests for users of the drug.

headline: London Britches Falling Down in Record Heat Wave
summary: British men wear shorts to work to keep cool, defying centuries of sartorial tradition as the city melts in 100-degree weather. ‘Can I wear shorts at Barclays?’

headline: Elizabeth Warren Vows to Make Trade Negotiations More Transparent
summary: Sen. Elizabeth Warren said she would revamp the way the U.S. makes trade deals, including by making the negotiation process more transparent and requiring strict labor, environmental and human-rights standards.

headline: Just Eat Can Wait for a More Satisfying Meal
summary: Britain’s food-delivery service Just Eat shared details of a possible $6 billion bid from Dutch rival Takeaway.com, but the deal could be more generous.

headline: A New Genetic Explanation for Anorexia
summary: The eating disorder, long viewed as a psychological condition, appears to have biological predictors that explain why gaining weight is harder for some patients.

headline: Trump Signs Bill Shoring Up 9/11 Victims Fund
summary: President Trump signed legislation that funds medical claims from victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks for the rest of their lives.

headline: In Detroit, Democrats Focus on Getting Black Voters to Polls
summary: For all of the debates over how Democrats should try to win over Trump voters in swing states like Michigan, a crucial plank in the party’s 2020 strategy lies in luring its own traditional supporters back to the polls, starting here in the city.

headline: Equifax Says Cultural Changes Since Breach Make It a Security Leader
summary: The credit-reporting firm says investments and new executives have helped it turn a corner on cybersecurity. Some security experts are skeptical that Equifax could become a cybersecurity benchmark.

headline: Cherry Capital of the U.S. Faces Threat From Turkish Imports
summary: Tart cherry farmers in Michigan are struggling to make a profit amid a flood of low-price dried cherries from Turkey.

headline: Colombia Has Produced Scores of World-Class Cyclists. They Now Have a Tour Winner.
summary: Egan Bernal’s victory in the Tour de France has special meaning in a country where many locals are obsessed with cycling.

headline: Labor Department Makes Public 401(k) Rule Change
summary: The Labor Department released a final rule to make it easier for small businesses to band together to create joint 401(k) retirement plans for workers.

headline: Trump Criticizes Expected Fed Rate Cut as ‘Not Enough’
summary: President Trump said that the Federal Reserve’s expected small interest-rate cut this week is “not enough,” but he expressed optimism that the country would do well regardless of what is decided.

headline: In TV Show, India’s Modi Takes a Walk on the Wild Side
summary: India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modiwill appear alongside British adventurer Bear Grylls in the country’s wilderness on an episode of his survival show “Man vs. Wild.”

headline: Stocks to Watch: Mylan, Merck, Booz Allen, Cooper Tire and More
summary: Shares of Mylan, Merck, Booz Allen, Cooper Tire, Mohawk Industries, Cabot Oil and Zimmer Biomet are expected to trade actively in Monday’s session.

headline: Trump Administration Boasts of Spending Deal Win
summary: Mick Mulvaney said the deal that passed the House last week enables Republicans to beat back Democratic policy goals.

headline: China Backs Hong Kong Chief and Police Crackdown on Protesters
summary: China’s top office for Hong Kong affairs used a rare news conference to endorse the territory’s leader and the police’s handling of increasingly violent clashes, signaling that Beijing is unlikely to yield concessions as it pressures the semiautonomous city to quell the unrest.

headline: Struggling Chinese Bank Gets Lifeline From State-Backed Investors
summary: Three of China’s state-backed financial institutions are to take stakes in a struggling commercial bank, indicating a different approach by regulators toward the country’s small troubled lenders.

headline: More Exchanges Add ‘Speed Bumps,’ Defying High-Frequency Traders
summary: High-frequency trading firms are hitting a growing number of mechanisms that impose a split-second delay before executing trades. Critics say the delays make markets unnecessarily complex and unfairly favor certain market participants.

headline: Now Calling Balls and Strikes: Robot Umpires
summary: Baseball’s future has arrived in the Atlantic League with the introduction an automated strike zone. If the experiment goes well, the days of players imploring umps to schedule an eye exam could soon come to an end.

headline: Grubhub’s Stock May Be Too Hard to Digest
summary: It shouldn’t be surprising that there is a food fight in the stock market over Grubhub. While the online food-delivery market continues to grow impressively, so does competition. Investors largely seem confident that food apps will continue to race ahead but they are less sure about which horse to bet on.

headline: Fed Prepares Rate Cut Amid Worries About Low Inflation
summary: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is leading his colleagues to cut interest rates this week for the first time since 2008, even though the economy looks healthy, partly because it isn’t behaving as expected.

headline: Netflix, Amazon May Be Forced to Make More Shows Down Under
summary: Netflix, Amazon and other video-streaming players may be required to produce more Australian content, the latest in a global push to compel tech giants to tailor their local offerings.

headline: For Many Diabetes Patients, Skin Patches and Phones Are Replacing Finger Pricks
summary: Diabetes patients increasingly rely on wearable glucose monitors and insulin pumps to manage a disease affecting some 30 million Americans—which is setting off fierce competition among makers of the devices.

headline: Enterprise Risk Management, Long Used by Companies, Takes Hold in Government
summary: Federal agencies are taking a cue from the corporate world, appointing chief risk officers and putting in place more processes to identify and manage operational risks.

headline: United Airlines Adds Biometric Clearance for Passengers
summary: United Airlines is taking an equity stake in Clear, a technology company that uses fingerprints and iris scans to verify a traveler’s identity at security checks.

headline: Indonesian Travel Startup Seeks to Raise Funds Valuing It at $4.5 Billion
summary: Traveloka, one of the largest online travel companies in Southeast Asia, is looking to raise $500 million in its latest funding round.

headline: What Do You Get for the Central Bank That Already Bought Everything?
summary: As the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank look likely to cut interest rates, the Bank of Japan has few options to follow them.

headline: Tarantino Scores Career-Best Opening Weekend With ‘Hollywood’
summary: Quentin Tarantino never stood a chance of usurping the family-friendly “The Lion King” from atop the box office, but with his latest film, “Once Upon a Time…in Hollywood,” the director won his best opening weekend on record.

headline: Deadly Bombing in Kabul Targets Afghan President’s Running Mate
summary: Official campaigning for presidential elections got off to an ominous start as suspected Taliban fighters attacked the Kabul political offices of President Ashraf Ghani’s running mate, leaving at least 20 people dead and dozens more wounded.

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: American Tech Shudders as China Cyber Rules Are Expected to Get Tougher
summary: U.S. businesses view proposed cybersecurity rules as new barriers to the Chinese market and they loom as a potential sticking point in coming trade talks.

headline: The Ultimate Luxury Vacation: Doing Nothing in the Middle of Nowhere
summary: In a bid to unplug, Americans are paying thousands of dollars to go off the grid; a $600 a night “iceberg nest.”

headline: Alleged 9/11 Mastermind Open to Helping Victims’ Lawsuit if U.S. Drops Death Penalty
summary: Alleged Sept. 11 mastermind Khalid Sheikh Mohammed has said he may be willing to help victims of the terrorist attacks in their lawsuit against Saudi Arabia if the U.S. government forgoes seeking the death penalty against him at a Guantanamo Bay military commission.

headline: Hospitals May Be Forced to Disclose Discount Rates Negotiated With Insurers
summary: Hospitals would have to disclose the discounted prices they negotiate with insurance companies under a Trump administration rule that could upend the $1 trillion hospital industry by revealing rates long guarded as trade secrets.

headline: Mylan Deal Furthers Pfizer CEO’s Bet on Patent-Protected Drugs
summary: A deal to merge Pfizer’s off-patent drugs business with generic drugmaker Mylan caps new Pfizer Chief Executive Albert Bourla’s remodeling of one of the world’s biggest pharmaceutical companies.

headline: Pound Falls After Boris Johnson Ramps Up No-Deal Brexit Rhetoric
summary: Prime Minister Boris Johnson refuses to hold face-to-face meetings with European Union leaders unless they agree to change key aspects to Britain’s divorce deal with the bloc, something the other 27 member states have refused to do, a stance that jolted the British currency.

headline: Kamala Harris Touts Tough-on-Banks Record. Others See a More Complicated Picture.
summary: Fellow negotiators in a 2012 settlement with U.S. lenders say Kamala Harris secured benefits for Californians in part at the expense of other parties, and some officials were rankled by her approach during the talks.

headline: Maya Hawke on ‘Stranger Things,’ Working With Quentin Tarantino and Staying in Touch With Her Generation
summary: The acting daughter of Uma Thurman and Ethan Hawke, who debuted in her first film this weekend, is becoming a star in her own right.

headline: Pfizer Nears Deal to Combine Off-Patent Drug Business With Mylan
summary: Pfizer is in talks to merge its off-patent drugs business with generic drugmaker Mylan, in a deal that would create a giant global seller of lower-priced medicines.
